Name: L.A. Noire (Game)
Description: L.A. Noire말s a third-person neo-noir crime video game developed byTeam Bondi말n conjunction with Rockstar North and Rockstar San Diego and published byRockstar Games. LA Noire is set in a nearly perfectly recreated 8 square miles of Los Angeles of 1947, with players being given an open-ended challenge to solve a series of crime and murder mysteries.

Name: Upon Reflection (Case 1-1)
Description: Upon Reflection말s a Patrol맊ase말nL.A. Noire. This is the first caseCole Phelps맚akes on the Patrol Desk, as well as the first case in the originalL.A. Noire. The case involves a murder in a back alley. Phelps finds the murder weapon and confronts him in his department.

Name: Armed and Dangerous (Case 1-2)
Description: Armed and Dangerous말s aPatrol맊ase inL.A. Noire. This case is about a robbery at Westlake Savings & Loans that Cole Phelps and his partner Ralph Dunn pick up on their car radio. When they arrive at the bank, Phelps takes a shotgun from the car's trunk and engages in a gun fight with the robbers.

Name: Warrants Outstanding (Case 1-3)
Description: Cole Phelps마ndRalph Dunn마re patrolling in their police vehicle when Dunn noticesWendell Bowers, who jumped his parole after being arrested by the former. Cole jumps out of the car and chases Wendell down, resulting in a fistfight.

Name: Buyer Beware (Case 1-4)
Description: While patrolling the streets, Officer Cole Phelps hears multiple gunshots and runs toward the sound. He shows up to the scene of a shooting where he discoversEverett Gage맋ead on the sidewalk in front of his own store,Nunn Bush Shoes, and learns the identity ofEdgar Kalou맍rom the store clerk,Clovis Galletta. He also finds .32 ACP shell casings, and a .32 ACPFN Browning 1922맗istol on the scene. Phelps and OfficerRalph Dunn많o toHartfield's Jewelry Store맚o locate their suspect, after confirming he is the owner of the handgun. Upon entering, they're greeted by Kalou who at first pretends to be someone else entirely, claiming Mr. Kalou is sleeping in the back. Kalou then attempts an escape. Phelps chases him through the store and out the back door and catches him. Phelps forces a confession from him in interrogation.

Name: Ralph Dunn
Description: Ralph Dunn말s a맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. Dunn serves asCole Phelps'맗artner맋uring the latter's time onPatrol.

Name: L.A. Noire Patrol Cases
Description: WhenCole Phelps맑oins the LAPD, he starts off as a police officer in this section as a막eat cop, based at theWilshire Police Station. This department is used as the game's tutorial, and its missions will teach the player the game's basics. Once Phelps completes all missions in this section, the LAPD will note that he has the ability to investigate crimes, and will promote him toDetective. Cole's맗artner말n this department is OfficerRalph Dunn.

Name: The Driver's Seat (Case 2-1)
Description: Cole Phelps and his new partner,Stefan Bekowsky, are called up to investigate an마bandoned car, which looks as if a murder was committed inside of it. Phelps also finds a receipt for a live pig in the trunk of the car, bought byFrank Morgan. Phelps meets with Margaret Black and learns of Adrian's affair. Phelps interviews Frank Morgan and he confesses Adrian is running away to Seattle for an affair and is at Morgan's apartment. Adrian is arrested.

Name: Adrian Black
Description: Criminal in "The Driver's Seat." He left his wife for a girl in Seattle and tried to get away by faking his death in an abandoned car.

Name: The Consul's Car (Case 2-X)
Description: Exclusive case. Phelps마ndStefan Bekowsky마re called up to investigate the theft of a diplomatic vehicle belonging toJuan Francisco Valdez, the Consul General of Argentina inLos Angeles. Phelps interrogates the owner of the car, Valdez (an Argentine consul). He admits being bribed to buy a car from Dewey, cites Gabriel as the culprit. Investigating Dewey reveals the same and visiting Gabriel's home shows the same. Finally an illegal street race ends in arrest.

Name: Oswald Jacobs
Description: Witness in "The Consul's Car." He is an old man who was first on the scene and gives you details about the criminals.

Name: Anna Rodriguez
Description: Witness in "The Consul's Car." She is the wife/girlfriend of Angel, the culprit. She covers for him and says his motive is honor.

Name: A Marriage Made in Heaven (Case 2-2)
Description: A Marriage Made in Heaven is a Traffic case in L.A. Noire. A man is found dead in the street in a hit and run. However there was a fight between the victim and his wife. The wife Lorna and Leroy the bar owner are "close." Questioning Lorna and Lester reveals motive for killing (life insurance and affair). Apprehends the hit and run culprit. Two endings, either Lorna is shot by Leroy or you just get Leroy at the bar.

Name: Malcolm Carruthers
Description: Coronor in L.A. Noire.

Name: Lorna Patterson
Description: Wife of victim in "A Marriage Made in Heaven." Hated her husaband and seen arguing with him before his death. Got a life insurance plan for him and was also having an affair with the bar owner. Gets shot if you get the evidence lol.

Name: A Slip of the Tongue (Case 2-3)
Description: A Slip of the Tongue말s a Traffic맊ase말nL.A. Noire. A seemingly run-of-the-mill car theft ends up sparking an explosive investigation into the largest auto fraud racket the city has ever seen. A stolen car is spotted and you chase it down. Interrogation reveals the car was purchased legitimately. The dealership reveals suspicions about the car sale by Jean Archer. Another man named James Belasco claims he owns the car he reveals that he delivers stolen cars. Questioning Jean Archer reveals she sold the car despite being in a ring. It is revealed that the printing company head Leitvol is in debt to people and participates in the auto ring. Leitvol eventually confesses and is arrested.

Name: Richard Coombs
Description: Used car salesman in "A Slip of the Tongue." He makes dumb jokes but is forthcoming and pragmatic during the investigation. He also has a good assessment of people.

Name: The Fallen Idol (Case 2-4)
Description: The Fallen Idol is a Traffic case in L.A. Noire. Phelps is told that June Ballard and Jessica Hamilton drove off a cliff. There are signs that Jessica had been drugged and raped during questioning of June and Jessica. Then tailing June Ballard reveals Bishop's location. Gloria Bishop reveals that Bishop was being blackmailed by Hopgood. Hopgood sells porn films of movie stars, but this time it was blackmail on Bishop now held by McAfee. Confrontation with Roy Earle and Bekowsky swags out on some of McAfee's men. At the end there's the first scene with Roy Earle and Elsa.

Name: June Ballard
Description: Witness in "The Fallen Idol." She is drugged and sent off a cliff. She is the wife of Guy McAfee and takes Jessica Hamilton to the casting audition, and allows her to be raped for a casting job.

Name: Gloria Bishop
Description: Wife of Mark Bishop in "The Fallen Idol." She tells Cole about the horrors of the town and how she has been disappointed. She calls out June Ballard and has swag.

Name: Marlon Hopgood
Description: Witness in "The Fallen Idol." He usually sells films of porn for movie directors. He helps June Ballard blackmail Bishop and gets money for it.

Name: Stefan Bekowsky
Description: Detective Stefan Bekowsky말s a central맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. Bekowsky isCole Phelps' partner while he is assigned to theTraffic맋esk and laterRusty Galloway's partner on theHomicide맋esk when Phelps is promoted toVice.

Name: Gordon Leary
Description: Captain of Traffic Department in L.A. Noire.

Name: L.A. Noire Traffic Cases
Description: TheTrafficDesk is a Department of theLos Angeles Police Department말nL.A. Noire. Traffic is concerned with hit-and-runs, stolen vehicles, felony driving, illegal street racing, and collision reports involving serious injuries or fatalities where a crime may have been involved.

Name: The Red Lipstick Murder (Case 3-1)
Description: The Red Lipstick Murder (aka: The Mendez Case or The Henry Case) is a Homicide case in L.A. Noire. The mission takes place six months after Cole's promotion. He and his new Homicide partner, Galloway, get a briefing from Capt. James Donnelly and drive to the crime scene. At the crime scene, on a hill called The Moors, they find the body, marked off by police tape. The victim found at the scene is naked, mutilated, and badly beaten. You see the footprint on the woman's chest, a message written in lipstick, and a piece of jewelry torn from her finger. One of the officers present then comes and brings some relevant information about the case, such as the fact that the characteristics of the injuries indicates that it is the action of the serial killer "The Werewolf." You meet Garrett Mason at the bar (omg) and question the bartender Dick McColl to reveal his secret crush on Celine Henry and the fact that the husband has no alibi. Basically it was heard that Celine and the husband Jacob are fighting a lot. You question Jacob and he seems upset about his wife's death but also was trying to get her "committed." You question Jacob and he is resolute, the Captain is very angry with you. You investigate the suspicious guy who left with Celine and arrest him after finding the evidence.

Name: Jacob Henry
Description: Suspect in "Red Lipstick Murder" in L.A. Noire. He is the wife of Celine Henry, a drinker. He was seen having an argument with his wife before she went to the bar, then did not repond to calls. A first interrogation reveals that he was planning to have her "committed" but is regretful overall. A second interrogation shows he is resolute in claiming to love his wife. He also never knew that the ring was bought by Dick McColl, the bar owner.

Name: The Golden Butterfly (Case 3-2)
Description: Cole is in the detectives' desk room with Rusty when James Donnelly calls him about another murder. Cole and Rusty head out to the crime scene to find that Donnelly is trying to fend off the swarm of reporters who are trying to get pictures and quotes. The captain tells them that he will address the media after the autopsy. The victim is Deidre Moller who was stomped and strangled. Questioning the daughter reveals that the husband is suspicious and they had fought before. You chase down Hugo after he is seen incinerating bloody shoes. You chase down Eli Rooney next. You interrogate them both and the true ending involves arresting Eli.

Name: Eli Rooney
Description: Suspect in "The Golden Butterfly." He is an alledged child sex offender. You find him creepily looking at children at a hight school. He has the butterfly brooch. Deidre Moller's car has stained overalls owned by Moller, the rope, and tire iron. Questioning reveals potential motive for money. He says he saw the car come and he took the Butterfly from the ground. Charged results in a good ending.

Name: Hugo Moller
Description: Suspect in "The Golden Butterfly." He is the husband of the victim. He paid off her wife with the golden butterfly brooch. Questioning reveals that he is insistent in his denial of being the murderer. Charged reveals a bad ending. Also there is the worst ending where he runs away as the janitor at the school accuses him of being the one that parks the car.

Name: The Silk Stocking Murder (Case 3-3)
Description: The Silk Stocking case starts out at a Downtown cafe, where Captain James Donnelly informs Phelps and Galloway of a brutally murdered woman left naked in an alleyway off of Aliso St., near City Hall. Upon arriving, Phelps and Galloway are greeted by a patrol officer, who then shows them to the body. The body has another message on it, like in the two previous cases. This one is cut up badly, but Phelps and Galloway argue whether it's a copycat murder or the original murderer still at large. Phelps soon finds a blood trail up the alleyway to a fire escape, then up the side and roof of a building to another set of roofs and eventually finds the victim's personal effects and library card along the way, as well as the victim's address and the fact that she was married. At the Maldanado residence is an you speak with the owner of these house. There are divorce papers and the window is found smashed. You beat up Angel and find a bloody shirt. At the bar it reveals she went to the Jush Picked Fruit Market for the phone. Investigating the market you find Clem Feeney who sells a ton of alcohol and also has some bloody evidence. You arrest him.

Name: Angel Maldanado
Description: Suspect in "The Silk Stocking Murder." Has no alibi and seen arguing with victim, the wife. He argued about divorce and slapped her, then she entered another car.

Name: Clem Feeney
Description: Suspect in "The Silk Stocking Murder." Runs the Just Picked Fruit Market, and sells booze after hours. The victim was seen here last night before going to some car. In the back of the store is a bloody scalpel, victim's bracelet, and tons of alcohol.

Name: The White Shoe Slaying (Case 3-4)
Description: The White Shoe Slaying is a Homicide case in L.A. Noire. Detectives Cole Phelps and Rusty Galloway are briefed about a murder that occurred on Signal Hill during a heavy rainstorm over Los Angeles. The two head over to the crime scene and check in with Officer Andy Brown, who has secured the scene, before meeting with the L.A. County Coroner, Malcolm Carruthers, and Ray Pinker from Tech Services. Unfortunately, the heavy rain washed away most of the evidence. Carruthers tells Phelps and Galloway that the murder is similar to the others: blunt head trauma and strangling, however, there were no messages on the body and the victim was clothed. Interrogating the husband reveals suspicions. At the bar you chase Richard Bates and he reveals that the victim ran off with a sailor and not him. Then you have to drive and stop the cab which the victim rode in. You question the sailor who is suspicious, he said she was lame and she fell asleep on his shoulder. You chase the bus driver and he confirms the story. You go to the hobo camp and have a fistfight with Ackerman. You find evidence on him and then charge him post interrogation.

Name: Stuart Ackerman
Description: Suspect in "The White Shoe Slaying." He's a homeless disfigured man who is head of the hobo camp. You find Theresa's purse and a bloody rope. He is crazy in the interrogation lol. He is also a communist lol.

Name: Lars Taraldsen
Description: Suspect in "The White Shoe Slaying." He is the husband of the victim. He was out at a party with his wife when she wanted to go dancing and he refused and she left. He went out late last night in the rain, but he can't be charged.

Name: The Studio Secretary Murder (Case 3-5)
Description: The Studio Secretary Murder is a Homicide case in L.A. Noire. First you check out a Pawnbroker who had the ring from Deidre Moller. It reveals nothing. The crime scene is by a railroad where Evelyn Summers. The guy who found the body was kissing the body. At the liquor store where she lived you find McCaffrey's book and a Bowling pin. The liquor store owner says she was getting booze as a present after a fight. He's pretty cool lol. He says she idolized McCaffrey but the feeling was not mutual. Really funny old lady at the bowling alley lol. Chase Tiernan. At Central the captain and everyone is riled up by the increasing number of corpses. At McCaffrey's apartment you find a bloody iron and shirt. You chase him down and interrogation begins. McCaffrey or Tiernan?

Name: Grosvenor McCaffrey
Description: Suspect in "The Studio Secretary Murder." You meet him in the bar and he reveals a criminal history of "worker's rights disputes" and reveals anger about a book being stolen. Interrogation reveals that Tiernan killed Evelyn and went to him for help. He alledgedly had all the stuff and said he would dispose of them. There is an exciting scene when you confront McCaffrey about his criminal history.

Name: James Tiernan
Description: Suspect in "The Studio Secretary Murder." You chase him down in the bowling alley and arrest him. Interrogation reveals he went with her to a hotel and passed out. He went with her to McCaffrey's to steal the book. Then she bought him a drink, and he was angry because of her obsession with McCaffrey.  After she left, he was at McCaffrey's and is unsure if he did it.

Name: The Quarter Moon Murders (Case 3-6)
Description: The Quarter Moon Murders is a Homicide case in L.A. Noire. This is the last case Cole Phelps takes on the Homicide Desk before he is promoted to the Vice Desk. Locations are the Fountain (nothing), Hall of Records (Chandelier),  Public Library (Climbing a lot), Tar Pits (platforming), Art Museum (maze), Intolerence Set (everything breaking and platforming balancing), Gunfight.

Name: Garrett Mason
Description: Garrett Mason말s a맊haracter말nL.A. Noire마nd the main antagonist of theHomicide맋esk.

Name: Rusty Galloway
Description: Detective Finbarr "Rusty" Galloway말s a central맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. Galloway wasFloyd Rose's partner whileCole Phelps말s in thePatrol마ndTraffic맋esk. Rusty became Cole's partner when Cole is promoted toHomicide마nd laterStefan Bekowsky's partner when Cole is promoted toVice.

Name: L.A. Noire Homicide Cases
Description: The Homicide desk is considered the most brutal and harrowing Department in the LAPD and is considered by many to be the prime detective assignment. Cole works the desk from the Central Police Station. His partner in Homicide is veteran Detective Rusty Galloway. The captain of the department is James Donnelly.

Name: James Donnelly
Description: Captain James Donnelly is a major character in L.A. Noire. He is Captain of the Homicide Department of the LAPD.

Name: The Black Caesar (Case 4-1)
Description: The Black Caesar is a Vice case in L.A. Noire. This is the first case Cole Phelps takes on the Vice Desk after being promoted from the Homicide Desk. Phelps and Earle report to the scene of two dead junkies, Cornell Eustace Tyree and Tyrone Anthony Lamont, found in a squalid apartment at 6358 Yucca St., Apt. 5, in Hollywood. Surgical tubing found still wrapped around their limp, track-pocked arms. Their drug of choice: government issue morphine. Your job is to track the morphine back to the supplier and bring them down. At the apartment Earle and Phelps get in an argument about the role of the law. Investigate the Black Caesar and then Roy says "hand over the popcorn, numskull, before we kick the door in" lol. The place sells popcorn and morphine at the bottom of these cups. Investigating Jermaine Jones reveals tons of weed, morphine, and money in the radio. Reveals connection to Lenny Finklestein and Merlon Ottie. Merlon Ottie has tons of drugs in the slot machine, which is also from Ramez Removals. You chase a delivery truck as it throws things at you lol. You search through the company and use a crane to get around. There is a ton of morphine in the ice. Finally at the Polar Bear Ice Company you shoot Lenny Finkelstein.

Name: Fleetwood Morgan
Description: Fleetwood Morgan is a character in L.A. Noire. He is a suspect in "The Black Caesar" case. Tyree and Lamont died from overdosing on the morphine. Detectives Cole Phelps and Roy Earle discovered the morphine syrettes taped to the bottom of popcorn cups, instantly implicating Morgan and his vendor. Phelps and Earle confronted him at his food hut. Morgan attempted to escape but was captured and questioned, during which he gave up Jermaine Jones as his supplier. Morgan was sent to prison for drug trafficking and resisting arrest.

Name: Jermaine Jones
Description: Jones ran a booking agency for musicians. Among his clientele were Cornell Tyree, Tyrone Lamont, Bowe and Bittleston. Jones was also part of Mickey Cohen's stolen morphine racket, working as a supplier along with Merlon Ottie. Both collected supplies of morphine from Lenny Finkelstein through deliveries from Ramez Removals. One of Jones' distributors was Fleetwood Morgan, who would sell the morphine by strapping them to the bottom of popcorn cups at the Black Caesar food hut. After the맋eaths of Lamont and Tyree from overdose, Morgan gave up Jones as his supplier in the morphine distribution. He was confronted by DetectivesCole Phelps마ndRoy Earle말n his office. They searched his office and discovered supplies of morphine as well as reefer hidden in his radio, which Phelps found마 note맍or, which what frequency the radio would have to be set to, in order to trigger the hidden switch. After sending two thugs to beat up the two detectives, which they failed, Jones was questioned. Despite his less forthcoming attitude, Jones eventually revealed he worked forLenny Finkelstein마nd Alan Shearer, then많ave up Merlon Ottie, revealing his illegal gambling establishment. Jones and his henchman were sent to prison for drug trafficking, however, Phelps promised to personally speak to theD.A.맚o help reduce his sentence in exchange for his cooperation. It is unknown if it actually happened or not.

Name: Merlin Ottie
Description: Ottie ran a legitimate bookmakers, but used an illegal wire system, the use of which was prohibited by laws of gambling. As a result, the corrupt LAPD Vice department extorted from Ottie, allowing him to keep his business, but had to bribe them. Ottie ran a number racket for Lenny Finkelstein, and was therefore part of the Cohen Crime Syndicate. Jose Ramez, a fellow associate of Lenny, was in debt to Ottie from gambling losses. To Ottie's annoyance and reluctance, Lenny and Ramez headed a stolen morphine distribution, and forced him to act as a supplier while taking over the gambling racket. Ottie was content to run the numbers and a clean establishment, but ended up resenting his positioning from ultimately being ordered around by Lenny and hustled by corrupt cops. While investigating the deaths of Tyrone Lamont and Cornell Tyree, Detectives Cole Phelps and Roy Earle learned from Fleetwood Morgan and Jermaine Jones of Ottie's "expansion" from gambling and into drugs. With a paper trail from the betting slips, they went to investigate Ottie's bookmakers. They found his wire service as well as morphine syrettes hidden in a slot machine, which Phelps opened with the combination of a cherry, a bell, and the word 'win'. Ottie attempted to escape, but was caught. After capturing Ottie, Phelps inspected Merlon's "wand", his antique cane, and found an I.O.U. note from Jose Ramez. During his interrogation, Ottie revealed that Lenny and Ramez forced him into their dope racket. Ottie was sent to prison for racketeering and drug trafficking.

Name: Reefer Madness (Case 4-2)
Description: Reefer Madness is a Vice case in L.A. Noire. Vice Narcotics receives a tip from one Freddie Calhoun, junkie, snitch and all around no-hoper. Freddie seems to be playing it straight for once, sharing information on a city-wide marijuana distribution ring. He outs Juan Garcia Cruz. After a firefight you find that all the drugs are stashed in soup cans. At the soup company it is revealed that the cans are filled at night, sent to 20th century market. There's a huge gunfight at the soup factory at night, and you are brought to Masangkay Metals. You catch the guy but he gets off because he knows people.

Name: The Set Up (Case 4-3)
Description: In 1947, professional boxerㅁlbert Hammond맏as won a fight that he was supposed to throw. His unexpected win cost his managerCarlo Arquero마nd several bookies, as well asMickey Cohen, a large amount of money, putting his life in danger. Hammond flees immediately after the fight. There they meet Mickey Cohen and have an intense confrontation. Seaching Albert's room reveals he is heading home with tons of money and the existence of Candy Edward's. You fight the manager and find out that Candy is also leaving town. You tail her and go to a bunch of bookmakers. You tail her via car to the bus depot. There she is shot and killed. Roy says it was Hammond after his greed over money split. When it turns out that she was killed by a knife so it's Carlos. Carlos is trying to kill Hammond and then you shoot him.

Name: Candy Edwards
Description: Candy was the girlfriend of L.A. boxer Albert Hammond. Candy learned of the prize win racket and Albert's dive in his upcoming fight with Kid Galahad, Candy attempted to persuade Albert to take the fall in order for everyone to make a profit and to avoid enraging the mob. However, Albert became stubborn over his personal pride hence Candy decided to leave him. Candy was attacked in her hotel room by Carlo Arquero, who was desperate for leads on the prize money and was demanding answers on Albert's whereabouts since he won the fight. Detectives Cole Phelps and Roy Earle arrived in time to beat up Arquero. Phelps quickly questioned Candy and her involvement. However, she denied knowing Albert's whereabouts or being part of the racket. With Hammond in hiding and his life in danger, Candy was free to take his betting slips and collected on his winnings at the various bookmakers throughout L.A., while unknown to her that she was being tailed by Phelps and Earle. After collecting all of Hammond's winnings, which accumulating a total of over $11,000, Candy prepared to leave Los Angeles. The winnings were covertly taken by Hammond who in actuality allowed Candy to collect them while he was maintaining a low profile. However, while in the bus terminal restroom, she was again attacked by Arquero, who fatally stabbed her and shot a round from her revolver to cover it up. Phelps arrived to aid Candy, but she died shortly thereafter from her knife wound before medical help could arrive.

Name: Carlos Arquero
Description: Under the urging of powerful gangster Mickey Cohen, Carlo convinced Albert Hammond to take a fall in his match against Kid Galahad - at least, he assumed he had, as he promised Hammond a reasonable sum. Word spread about Hammond taking a dive and that many powerful people had a lot of money on it, including Roy Earle and many other Vice detectives. On fight night, however, Hammond was too prideful to take the dive. He knocked out Galahad, winning the fight, before escaping out of the locker room window. Arquero was furious, knowing that if he didn't get Hammond, he would be killed, as many powerful people had money on Galahad. Cohen sent his men out looking for Hammond while Arquero went to interrogate Hammond's girlfriend, Candy Edwards. Before getting anything out of Edwards, Phelps and Earle arrived at Candy's apartment and found Arquero assaulting her. Cole proceeded to fistfight Arquero. After knocking him out, he picked up and examined a deadly weapon, and a notebook containing the names of several bookmakers. Phelps and Earle then interviewed Candy, who didn't want to press charges against Arquero, but she did want him to leave the apartment. Carlo regained consciousness shortly afterwards and left, but Earle told him that he was personally handling the matter, and warned him not to do anything stupid. After Edwards collected her and Hammond's winnings from the bets they'd placed on him to win at various bookmakers, Arquero found Edwards in a bus depot in Hollywood. He stabbed her in the chest and shot a round out of Candy's Smith & Wesson revolver as cover, killing her within seconds. However, Candy's murder caught the attention of the LAPD, who revealed that him stabbing her was her official cause of death, adding that the revolver was actually hers. Arquero then went to the Egyptian Theatre to kill Hammond, though once again Phelps and Earle arrived. Cole killed Arquero and let Hammond go with the money, much to the annoyance of Earle and the mystification of the police force. Phelps announced to advancing police forces that Hammond must've skipped town after the fight and was never at the theater, the truth lost to all but himself and Roy. Lieutenant Archie Colmyer then congratulated them for successfully wrapping up and solving Candy's murder.

Name: Albert Hammond
Description:
During the fight withKid Galahad, Hammond pretended to be losing the fight, but ultimately망on with a knockout, inciting the outrage of the many spectators who lost their bets. Hammond immediately went to his locker room, climbed through the window and made a run, realizing that a hit would be placed on his head for not taking the fall. While in hiding, Hammond simply allowed Candy to take the betting slips to the bookmakers to collect his winnings. Hammond was able to covertly collect the winnings off Candy at the bus terminal but she was then murdered by Arquero.

"Why did you kill her, Carlo? Your gripe was with me."
?Albert Hammond
Albert Hammond is a character in L.A. Noire. He is a central character in the Vice case, "The Set Up".

Contents[show]
Biography
Background
A British National who fought in the Second World War as a Royal Marine Commando, and also was Royal Navy boxing champion. After the war was over, he moved to Los Angeles and continued a career in boxing with Carlo Arquero as his manager, and Candy Edwards as his girlfriend.

Arquero deemed Hammond as a "washed up" fighter with his career going nowhere. Mickey Cohen would later urge Arquero to force Hammond to take a dive in his upcoming fight with Kid Galahad. Rumors of this outcome would spread causing a prize win racket, profiting off Hammond's loss in the fight. Hammond resented being used and decided to go against Arquero's wishes. Hammond placed bets on himself throughout various bookmakers, he calculated the odds and his winnings would sum up to over $11,000.

Events of L.A. Noire
During the fight with Kid Galahad, Hammond pretended to be losing the fight, but ultimately won with a knockout, inciting the outrage of the many spectators who lost their bets. Hammond immediately went to his locker room, climbed through the window and made a run, realizing that a hit would be placed on his head for not taking the fall. While in hiding, Hammond simply allowed Candy to take the betting slips to the bookmakers to collect his winnings. Hammond was able to covertly collect the winnings off Candy at the bus terminal but she was then murdered by Arquero.

Arquero confronted Hammond at the Egyptian Theater. Hammond chastised Arquero for killing Candy and for using him. Arquero attempted to kill Hammond and take the winnings, however, Arquero was killed in a gunfight with arrival of Cole Phelps and Roy Earle. Phelps empathized with Hammond's notions of courage as a marine, hence allowed him a chance to leave L.A. with the winnings but warned him not to return for his own safety.

Name: The Naked City (Case 4-4)
Description: The Naked City말s aVice맊ase말nL.A. Noire. Julia Randall, a stunning fashion model with the world at her feet, is found dead in her own bathtub. To the Homicide squad it looks like a textbook society-type's suicide - just another glamorous life ended early by the victim's own hand - but coroner Malcolm "Mal" Carruthers remains unconvinced. The victim has tons and tons of sleeping pills and Benzedrine. Questioning the housekeeper reveals that the modeling job paid suspiciouly much, the existence of a Mr. Henderson, and she was super moody. At her modeling company, the mystery thickens when her friend doesn't know about "Mr. Henderson." There's another body of Jimmy Leblanc, a burglar with syrettes who was a thief and may be the killer. Roy is very skeptical lol. You question Henry Arnett, a friend of Julia. He reveals he knows nothing and lies about being in the marines. You tail him, and he is leaving town in two days. It is revealed that Arnett and Julia both have stolen property. You interview Evestrom, and Roy drinks lol. During the burglary, Evestrom was at a party hosted by Dr. Stoneman. Then after questioning the friend of Julia arrives and she is the daughter?!  You drive her to Arnett's place. There you chase and get knocked out. You question Arnett and he reveals his involvement with burglary, and that he paid the others to kill Julia, and that Henderson is Stoneman. At Henderson's he kills himself. You kill Willy and he case ends.

Name: Henry Arnett
Description: Through his fashion business Arnett worked and became involved with Julia Randall. Like many men, Arnett became quickly enamored and involved with Julia. In turn, Julia manipulated Arnett into resorting to crime and robbery to support her materialistic needs. Julia used her doctor, Harold Stoneman, to acquire the names and addresses of wealthy high society members, while Arnett robbed them with the aid of Wilson "Willy the Wolf" Reade and Jimmy Leblanc. Through Julia, Arnett also met and fell in love with Heather Swanson and ended his relations with Julia but would still continue committing burglaries on her behalf. Arnett and Heather got engaged at some point and gave her a pearl ring as an engagement ring, which was ironically a stolen item. Eventually, Julia's insatiable demand for money and merchandise was too much for Arnett, and his business went broke in order to support her. Arnett confronted Julia, and told her that he wanted out of their relationship. However, Julia laughed back at him, hence Arnett decided to escape his predicament, by having Julia murdered by Willy and Jimmy. Although Julia's death was made to look like suicide, Cole Phelps began to suspect murder, and would question Arnett and his involvement with Julia. Arnett tried to distract Phelps by stating he was in Captain of Marines and fought in Okinawa. However, Phelps saw through his lie and strongly suspected his motives. Phelps and Roy Earle followed Arnett, and discovered he had pawned a rare stolen Faberge cigarette case for a mere $600, and bought a one-way ticket to Mexico City. Arnett did so in haste as he realized that the truth of Julia's death would come out, hence he wanted to escape the city before he could be arrested, and was prepared to leave his fiancee behind. At his apartment preparing to leave L.A., he was attacked by Willy who then quickly eluded Phelps' custody. Arnett regained consciousness with Heather at his side, with Phelps ready to question him. Phelps presented plenty of evidence of Arnett's involvement, and he was compelled to admit the truth that he committed the burglaries, and paid Willy and Jimmy to kill Julia to get out of her gang. Arnett then revealed that Henderson was actually an alias for Stoneman, who was also involved with Julia and the robberies. With Willy, Jimmy, and Julia killed and Dr. Stoneman later committing suicide, Arnett was the only survivor of the gang, and was sent to prison.

Name: Heather Swanson
Description: Heather worked as a model forㅁrnett Clothing Emporium. She was engaged toHenry Arnett마nd was close friends withJulia Randall. Heather and Julia later moved to work at theD'Assine Dress Shop, though Julia had a notorious reputation as a flirtatious troublemaker, hence was later fired. While working at the fashion store, Heather was introduced to Detectives Cole Phelps and Roy Earle by Celia Stanley. Phelps questioned Heather for background information on Julia and asked Heather to request Arnett come to Hollywood Police Station for questioning. Before leaving, Phelps revealed that Julia had been murdered, upsetting Heather. Later that evening at home, she encountered both Phelps and Earle again, who were informing her mother of her recovered stolen items. Phelps revealed that Arnett was involved in the burglaries. Outraged by the accusation, Heather was escorted by Phelps and Earle to Arnett's apartment, where they witnessed Arnett being attacked though the assailant escaped. Phelps interrogated Arnett, with strong evidence. Heather learned the shocking truth that Arnett and Julia were both part of burglary gang. Arnett stole from Heather's mother, and her pearl engagement ring was also stolen. Furthermore, Phelps revealed that Arnett planned to escape to Mexico City, leaving Heather behind to escape the authorities. Arnett was sent to prison for burglary, and their engagement was likely cancelled.

Name: Harold Stoneman
Description: Stoneman fell in love with Julia Randall, who, sadly enough, did not return his affections. Instead, Julia used him as part of her schemes to make more money. Stoneman's wife would often throw high society parties, through her he would give the names of wealthy people to Julia so she along with Henry Arnett could burgle their houses for money and jewelry. Stoneman continued showering as much money as he could unto Julia hoping she would eventually love him in return. However, Julia didn't even allow Stoneman to touch her, she constantly strung him on the promise they would be together but was merely using him. While affiliated with Julia he went by the alias of "Henderson" to protect his identity and from others finding out the truth about Julia and her involvement. After Julia was murdered, Detectives Cole Phelps and Roy Earle visited his practice and informed him of Julia's death. He tried to tell the detectives that Julia had only been a patient of his for about six months. However, Phelps disproved this lie by using Julia's prescription as evidence, showing that she had been a patient of Stoneman since July 1946. After Henry Arnett revealed that 'Mr. Henderson' and Stoneman are the same person, he was again confronted at his practice by Phelps and Earle. Realizing that he had gone insane with grief, and accepting "Prison would be better than insanity..." Stoneman admitted his involvement in the burglaries and promised to testify in court. However, Stoneman refused a lawyer and even to see his own family, in regret and realizing he had ruined his life, Stoneman committed suicide by jumping out of an open window, and landing on top of a car.

Name: Manifest Destiny
Description: Manifest Destiny is a Vice case in L.A. Noire. The case starts out with a triple homicide at the 111 Club on Hollywood Blvd. Although the Homicide division is of course on the scene, Vice is called in due to the presence of yet more Army surplus morphine. There you find stolen BARs, morphine, and cigarettes. You question the hostess and it's Eddie McGoldrick one of the army veterans. You then interview Elsa and she tells you nothing basically, and then she grills you and owns you. Then Cole has an affair with Elsa. Roy Earle sees.  Then you talk with Mickey Cohen. After that you find the records of the ship robbery. There's a bus shooting. You interview the driver, Felix (from the marines). He reveals Kelso is in L.A. and you pick him up lol. During the interview he tells you nothing and you just tell him stuff lol. Two shootouts later... and one almost dead guy is telling you that they got wrecked. Finally you meet Sheldon and he's about to confess everything and then Phelps gets demoted. There's a cutscene where Cole argues with his wife then gets kicked out and goes to Elsa's place.

Name: Elsa Lichtmann
Description: Elsa Lichtmann말s a central맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. She is the singer atThe Blue Room맕ightclub.

Name: Mickey Cohen
Description: Meyer Harris "Mickey" Cohen말s a맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. Cohen is one of the main antagonists duringCole Phelps' time on theVice맋esk, along withCourtney Sheldon.

Name: Jack Kelso
Description: Jack Kelso말s the deuteragonist말nL.A. Noire. Kelso is a former United States Marine who has a history withCole Phelps마t theBattle of Okinawa. After the war and his discharge from the Marine Corps, he became a claims investigator forCalifornia Fire and Life.

Name: Courtney Sheldon
Description: Courtney Sheldon말s a central맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. He is a former Navy Corpsman serving with the United States Navy and Marine Corps, having fought at Okinawa alongside LieutenantCole Phelps마nd SergeantJack Kelso마s a field medic. Sheldon acts as a one of the main antagonists (though unaware) during theVice맋esk.

Name: Harlan Fontaine
Description: Dr. Harlan J. Fontaine, PHD말s a central character and one of the main antagonists of theㅁrson맋esk. He is a clinical psychiatrist who is featured several times on the front page story of theLos Angeles Inquisitor. Throughout the game's events, the majority of his appearances are in newspaper flashbacks.

Name: Archibald Colmyer
Description: Lt. Archibald "Archie" Colmyer말s a맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. He is a lieutenant in theLos Angeles Police Department'sVice맛nit.

Name: L.A. Noire Vice Cases
Description: Theㅁdministrative Vice, also known asVice,ㅁd Vice, orVice NarcoticsDesk is aDepartment맖f theLos Angeles Police Department말nL.A. Noire. It deals with offenses involving prostitution, narcotics, lewdness, lasciviousness, and obscenity. LAPD Vice detectives plunge themselves down into the "seedy underbelly of L.A.", overturning the most decrepit of stones to expose the city's drugs, druggies, pimps, pushers, prostitutes, bootleggers, bookies, mob lords, thugs and gangsters. Working these cases will defyPhelps' worst and lowest expectations of humanity. Cole starts to work in this department following a harrowing stint investigating murders on theHomicide맋esk withRusty Galloway, to find that things can indeed get even more vicious inLos Angeles. Cole is specially requested by Chief Detective of Vice,Roy Earle, For a reassignment from Homicide. Cole works the Vice desk at theHollywood Police Station. His partner is Roy Earle, the senior Ad Vice맋etective. In Vice, Phelps has two commanding officers in the department,CaptainLazarus Cafarelli마ndLieutenantㅁrchie Colmyer. Vice is said to be the most "glamorous" of all the departments and one of the prime detective assignments, second only to the Homicide Department. However, the Vice Department also seems to be the most corrupt department of the LAPD. Vice detectives tend to be ruthless, dishonest, and easily swayed by money. They also seem to have the most power, due to Vice's status as the most glamorous department. As such, members get an extraordinary amount of leeway uncommon in the LAPD or the District Attorney's Office. For example, Roy Earle, the Chief Detective, is bribed byLeland Monroe맚o ensure Dr.Harlan Fontaine's illegal use of morphine on his patients is kept secret, and also rats out Cole's secret affair withElsa Lichtmann말n order to draw away attention from a Vice scandal.

Name: Roy Earle
Description: Detective Roy Earle is a central character in L.A. Noire. Roy is the corrupt Chief Detective of the Vice department. He is Cole Phelps' partner during his time at the Vice desk. Roy later becomes a secondary antagonist during the Arson desk.

Name: The Gas Man (Case 5-1)
Description: The Gas Man is an Arson case in L.A. Noire. This is the first case Cole Phelps takes on the Arson desk after being demoted from the Vice desk due to the scandal he caused. Phelps joins arson and everyone is roasting him. You are partnered with Biggs and he is not amused at all. There are two house fires to investigate. The first one is Steffens family, who won a competition and were out of town when they came back to a fire. He tells you that his house was the last one to be purchased from the suburban redevelopment fund and you also see some instaheat heater. At he Sawyer house you meet the coroner. Cole says he needs to get something before the department ruins him. You chase down Herbert Chapman, a suspect. Biggs and Cole have an argument, Cole always has to be a hero and its probably just nothing but Cole is insistent. Both the Sawyer family and Steffens were offered prizes, by the Suburban Redevelopment Fund. Then you force the guy at the travel agency to donate money lol. You go to the fire station and Lynch makes you make a balloon explode. You go to Instaheat and and find the stuff has been tampered with and get an employee/suspect list. Ryan and Clemens are both anarchists while Varley has a moquito coil. Clemens is innocent, and you chase down Ryan and Varley. You interrogate Ryan and he says that he hates Instaheat and accuses Varley of being with Suburban Redevelopment. Varley tells you that Suburban gave Sawyer a free heater service, and that the moquito coils belong to Ryan.

Name: Herbert Chapman
Description: Herbert Chapman is a character in L.A. Noire. He is a person of interest in "The Gas Man" case and later a suspect in "A Walk in Elysian Fields", acting as a secondary antagonist for the early Arson cases. After hearing about the Sawyer house fire, Chapman arrived at the scene, but was recognized by Lynch and Biggs. Chapman instantly became a suspect, and was apprehended by Detective Cole Phelps. He was arrested under suspicion of causing the fire, but was released, as there was no evidence linking him to the fire. Chapman worked as a waybill for Elysian Fields Development, handing out promotional flyers to holdouts. Leland Monroe framed Chapman as a scapegoat for the Morelli house fire. Cole Phelps and Herschel Biggs went to his house to arrest him. In the trunk of his van, they discovered a box of .45 ACP rounds, promotional flyers and a box of mosquito coils. The detectives then spotted him across the street outside a laundromat. Chapman drew a gun and attempted to escape by hijacking a tram, but he was eventually stopped when Phelps and Biggs derailed the trolley. Chapman was ultimately killed in a shootout with Phelps and Biggs. Phelps said he couldn't imagine Chapman and Leland Monroe working together, due to the fact the fires always benefited Elysian Fields in some way. Biggs agreed, but said that the evidence was good for Chapman, especially due to his firearm.

Name: Albert Lynch
Description: Albert Lynch is a character in L.A. Noire. He is a fire investigator, who operates out of the Engine Company No. 27 fire station. While investigating the Sawyer house, Lynch was met by Biggs and Cole Phelps, though Lynch was surprised that Biggs had a partner. While examining the scene, Lynch caught sight of Chapman and pointed him out to Phelps. Chapman was arrested by Phelps under suspicion of causing the fire. After discovering the tampered regulator valve, Lynch demonstrated a theory with gas experiment and the regulator valve. The experiment indicated that the arsonist was sabotaging water heater regulator valves to cause the house fires. Lynch suggested investigating InstaHeat for leads on the water heater models. Lynch along Malcolm Carruthers, Biggs and Phelps later investigated the gruesome Morelli house fire, the bodies of the family charred and twisted from the "prayer effect". Lynch carefully inspected the remains and the scene. His analysis indicated that the arsonist moved the bodies, possibly out of guilt, leading to a complicated theory regarding the true arsonist.

Name: Matthew Ryan
Description: Ryan worked as an installer for Hephaistos Water Heater Company. However, his family died in a fire accident shortly after he installed a water heater in his own home, due to the heater's faulty and unreliable design. Ryan was assumed responsible and taken to court. Since Hephaistos could not be held liable for the fire despite the flaws in their water heater design, Ryan was forced to take the blame. Despite no criminal intent, he was charged for attempted murder. Ryan became a fifth columnist hoping to expose and sabotage other "fascist" water heater companies and would hand out fifth columnist pamphlets to other employees at InstaHeat. However, he was shunned because he was viewed as a communist sympathizer. While installing heaters for InstaHeat, Ryan became a맙uspect for a series of house fires막ecause of his criminal record. He was approached by detectivesCole Phelps마ndHerschel Biggs. He immediately fled in his truck, but crashed and was apprehended. After being interrogated, Ryan was charged for the fires as well for the murders of the Sawyer family and sent to prison. However, Phelps later realized that neither Ryan, Reginald Varley or Herbert Chapman were responsible. It is ultimately revealed that Ira Hogeboom was responsible for the fires, and Ryan was released.

Name: Reginald Varley
Description: Varley previously lived in Detroit where he committed an act of murder. He fled to Los Angeles to escape the authorities. While in L.A., Varley worked as a contractor for InstaHeat, he did installments and maintenance for the company's customers. Varley's boss, Ivan Rasic overlooked Varley's warrant for murder due to the need to hire installers. Varley was approached by the Suburban Redevelopment Fund (SRF) who requested his help in order help further their housing plans. Varley accepted their bribe and installed water heaters into the new housing developments. Varley also did free maintenance services on Sawyer and Morelli home water heaters. These families were holdouts, hence Varley correctly suspected that the SRF gave free service as incentive to sell to Elysian Fields Development. Due to his murder warrant and employment with InstaHeat, Varley became a suspect for a series of arsons. To add to the suspicion, a box of mosquito coils, a favored time delayed fuse for arsonists, was found in Varley's locker. However, Varley was actually holding them for Matthew Ryan since his locker was filled with fifth communist pamphlets. Varley was approached and arrested by detectives Cole Phelps and Herschel Biggs at his work site. During interrogation, Phelps suspected that Varley's motive was part of the foul play by the SRF, however, Varley deflected any indications of a conspiracy. With Ryan being charged for the arsons, Varley was extradited back to Detroit and was incarcerated for his murder charge.

Name: A Walk in Elysian Fields (Case 5-2)
Description: A Walk in Elysian Fields is an Arson case in L.A. Noire. At the Morelli House you find corpses in the house with the Prayer effect. Biggs storms out when you want evidence of a repeat offender. You talk with him and he agrees that you will find him. You hear Morelli was not selling to the Suburban Redevelopment fund. The captain tells you to stay away from Elysian Fields. For some reason there's a fight at Rancho Escondido? The house quality is awful at this other place. You see Monroe and question him. He gives you a list of suspects with Herbert Chapman and also says that the Chief of Police and Mayor are in on it. There's a cutscene between Roy and Cole at the Blue Room where Roy tells Cole to stay away. You arrest Chapman and the case closes, Elysian Fields gets away. Chapman has moquito coils, flyers for Elysian, and guns in his trunk. He hijacks the trolley lol. After the case Elsa gets a letter for Lou's death and Cole tells Elsa to reject the claim and ask Jack to investigate.

Name: Leland Monroe
Description: Leland Monroe is a central character in L.A. Noire, as well as one of the main antagonists during the Arson desk cases.

Name: House of Sticks (Case 5-3)
Description: House of Sticks is an Arson case in L.A. Noire, although it does not involve the police. Elsa comes to Kelso and asks for help in investigating. Kelso is skeptical. You talk with Mr. Benson and he tells you to stay out of Elysian. You go anyway and finds a receipt for cheap cement, demolition order for the house of interest, and a connection to Monroe. The house of interest has been demolished but you find the wood is from a film studio. You get chased around by a bulldozer lol. Then you go to the Film Studio and see the quality of lumber is bad, you play a film that indicts Fontaine, Bensen, Monroe in the Suburban Bensen. You call Bensen and he tells you to f off. Kelso calls Elsa and and they meet at the Blue Room, and then Elsa talks with Cole, Cole is jealous lol. Then Kelso gets beat up at the development site and make a car getaway barely. Stumbles into Elsa's apartment and the case ends. Funny scene where Kelso says hi to Cole and then collapses.

Name: Curtis Benson
Description: Curtis Robert Benson말s a맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. Benson is the Vice-president ofCalifornia Fire and Life, and is also on the board of directors of theSuburban Redevelopment Fund. Curtis is later revealed as one of the main antagonists duringCole Phelps' time onㅁrson마ndJack Kelso's time as an investigator forCalifornia Fire and Life마nd the District Attorney's Office.

Name: A Polite Invitation (Case 5-4)
Description: A Polite Invitation is an Arson case in L.A. Noire. It is also the second of three cases in the game where you play as Jack Kelso throughout the entire case. Kelso wakes up in the hospital and talks to Elsa. Then Jack gets an offer from Petersen to be a D.A.'s investigator. Jack goes to Bensen's apartment and then interrogates and searches. An interrogation reveals nothing new, other than that "it's all in the case file." Checking the file reveals a latitude and longitude and a property cost which is minimal. Phelps and Jack have a chat about how Cole is sorry and Jack needs to help. Jack gives a speech about how Cole shouldn't be guilty for his nonsense medal. At the hall of records you find the Suburban Redevelopment Fund shareholders and the price of the site being worth 10 times the land with a house. There's a gunfight. Kelso talks with Courtney about the Suburban Redevelopment Fund and he confesses that he gave the morphine to Fontaine. Kelso gets a call from Monroe and there's an exciting and long shootout. Kelso gets shot by the secretary. A search of the office reveals a payroll for Earle, and other execs in LAPD. There is also a file assemblede by Roy Earle on Fontaine's criminal activity.

Name: Nicholson Electroplating (Case 5-X)
Description: Nicholson Electroplating is an Arson case in L.A. Noire. The case begins with Phelps and Biggs discussing the whereabouts of Jack Kelso, currently the subject of a state-wide APB. No mention is made of Elsa Lichtmann and her kidnapping, nor of the death of Harlan Fontaine, as this case begins during A Polite Invitation, presumably after Cole has visited Jack's office but before the shootout at Leland Monroe's Mansion. Suddenly, a huge explosion, complete with a mushroom cloud, occurs a few blocks away. Biggs at first thinks the Soviets have launched a hydrogen bomb at Los Angeles. You kill two looters there and it's the remains of Nicholson Electroplating. There is an airplane part, laundry tag, and omg Ralph Dunn is here.  In a briefcase, you find a spy camera  and there is a secret address and a Japanese man's business card. You interview Fred Nicholson and he tells you about Tamako Okamoto, an industrial spy and Harold McLellan, the chemist in charge of these experiments which blew everything up. At Okamoto's apartment you find a dead man in the refrigerator, an LAPD retirement tiepin, and some microfilm. You goes to Hughes Aircraft and interrogate Vernon Mapes an LAPD retiree. It seems Hughes were sending stuff to Nicholson for polishing without the boss knowing about it. For some reason inside the plane there is a destination of the Bahamas. In Mapes' office there are images of Marie McDonald. You find that McLellan was giving the patent of the experiment for Hughes and Okamoto snagged a photo of it. You check out a suspicious house and it turns out the it's the house of McLellan (a false name) and there's gas all over the floors. Mapes tries to set you on fire but you escape. You chase him down and then kill him.

Name: Vernon Mapes
Description: Mapes is a former LAPD officer who worked in the Vice department. He was a notorious crooked cop and was hated by honest cops such as Herschel Biggs and Lachlan McKelty. His career as a corrupt officer was well known, and he was admired by up and coming cops such as Roy Earle. After retiring from the police force, Mapes became the head of security for Howard Hughes' Los Angeles headquarters, Hughes Aircraft. Mapes also acted as head of Hughes' personal interests outside of Hughes Aircraft, such as arranging seedy business deals and organizing prostitution for Hughes with Hollywood starlets. Mapes learned of Harold McLellan's formula to chemically polish aluminum, a process of extreme value to Hughes Aircraft, and hence established a business arrangement with McLellan. Their deal involved McLellan personally selling the process to Hughes through Mapes while cutting out Fred Nicholson. Mapes also provided McLellan with a prop spinner for testing. Unfortunately, Lockheed, an aircraft manufacturing competitor, was also aware of the process and resorted to industrial espionage to steal it from McLellan. Mapes in turn murdered an unnamed Lockheed employee, an accomplice of Tomoko Okamoto, and hid the body at her apartment. Mapes' intent was to eliminate competitors for the process and to secure it for Hughes. Unfortunately, both McLellan and Okamoto were killed in a massive explosion at the Nicholson Electroplating Plant, when a test of the formula went horribly wrong. Detectives Cole Phelps and Biggs arrived at Hughes Aircraft to investigate links to the Nicholson Electroplating explosion. Mapes allowed them into the hangar and answered a few questions. Mapes later proceeded to burn down McLellan's home, in order to remove evidence of his corrupt deeds and implicating Hughes. However, he was caught by Phelps and Biggs, prompting Mapes to flee back to the hangar and after a car chase, Mapes was finally killed in a shootout.

Name: A Different Kind of War (Case 5-5)
Description: A Different Kind of War is an Arson case in L.A. Noire. This is the last case Cole Phelps takes on the Arson Desk, as well as the last case in L.A. Noire. The case starts when Elsa confronts Fontaine about his involvement in the Elysian Fields. "I can see your future, Elsa." Fontaine knocks out Elsa but then Ira kills the doctor. In the first part of the case, you play as Jack Kelso. Jack is shown outside the Los Angeles International Speedway, preparing to investigate a number of exterminators around LA after Leland Monroe informed him that the serial arsonist was a bug-sprayer. The next section of the case takes you back to the previous day. You play as Cole Phelps again. Cole and Biggs are called in by Rusty Galloway to investigate the murder of Dr. Harlan Fontaine at his home office by one of his patients, as well as the kidnapping of Elsa Lichtmann. You search the place and find tons of morphine, blackmail papers on Fontaine from Monroe, and finally a highway map which shows the highway will be built straight over new houses. Cole figures out the plan is for the government to buy the land in the path of the freeway which has value from the insurance. The third section of the case has you play Jack Kelso again. Kelso checks out the bunkhouse at the old Rancho Rincon. Jack soon realizes that the arsonist and occupant of the bunkhouse is his and Cole's former fellow Marine, Ira Hogeboom, responsible for burning out a cave of innocent civilians during the war, under Cole's orders. He had since lost his mind and gone to Dr. Fontaine for help. Fontaine, however, working with Leland Monroe, had Ira burn down the homes in the Arson cases The Gas Man and A Walk in Elysian Fields, killing two families in the process. When Fontaine knocked out Elsa Lichtmann in his office, Hogeboom burst in and strangled the doctor. Jack, after finding the map of the Los Angeles River Tunnels, comes to the conclusion that Hogeboom resides down there with Elsa as his hostage. There's a vehicle chase where Cole helps Kelso get away from the police after him. The DA who hired Jack, Peterson stalls the police outside the place. There is a long long shoot sequence in the tunnels. Jack confronts Ira who has Elsa. Cole comes and Ira says Cole commanded him to kill all those innocent civilians during the war. Jack kills Ira. Cole dies as Elsa and Jack escape. The final scene is the funeral with Roy Earle giving a speech. The final scene is Courtney recommending everyone to steal morphine. Jack gives a speech about how everyone is a hero.

Name: L.A. Noire Arson Cases
Description: TheㅁrsonDesk is a Department of theLAPD말nL.A. Noire. Arson is concerned with crimes of maliciously, voluntarily, and willfully setting fire to buildings, forest areas, other property of another, or of burning one's own property for an improper purpose, such as to collect insurance. The Arson Desk also works side-by-side with theLos Angeles Fire Department마nd fire investigatorㅁlbert Lynch.

Name: Herschel Biggs
Description: Detective Herschel Biggs말s a central맊haracter말nL.A. Noire. He isCole Phelps' final partner upon Phelps' demotion to theㅁrson맋esk fromVice.

Name: Lachlan McKelty
Description: Captain Lachlan McKelty is a character in L.A. Noire. He is the Captain of the LAPD's Arson Department.

Name: Newspaper 1
Description: Seen in "Upon Reflection," Courtney Sheldon talks with Fontaine and asks him to help his friend.

Name: Newspaper 2
Description: Seen in case "The Driver's Seat." In it, Dr. Fontaine is seen talking with Ira Hogeboom and giving him drugs to help alleviate his PTSD.

Name: Newspaper 3
Description: Seen in "A Marriage Made in Heaven," Courtney confronts Fontaine about his patients being addicts and doing illegal drugs. Fontaine explains that it is better for society.

Name: Newspaper 4
Description: Seen in "The Fallen Idol." Mickey Cohen and Courtney Sheldon talk about how Cohen is upset that Sheldon is supplying unadulterated drugs to the market. He offers a bribe and is refused. Then Cohen asks for Sheldon to be killed.

Name: Newspaper 5
Description: Ira is calling Dr. Fontaine and complaining about how the house that he burned was full of people when Ira burned it and he watched them die.

Name: Newspaper 6
Description: Courtney Sheldon comes asking Jack Kelso for help with the gangsters who are giving addicts morphine. He asks them to negotiate.

Name: Newspaper 7
Description: There's a standoff between Mickey Cohen and Jack Kelso and Courtney Sheldon. Jack Kelso says the morphine will be going into the sea. Epic line where Courtney tells Cohen that Japs which are "little guys" are "about your size."

Name: Newspaper 8
Description: Courtney Sheldon talks to Harlain Fontaine about how he robbed the ship of morphine. The doctor offers to help by take all the drugs and "medically administer" them, then invest them in phony housing projects.

Name: Newspaper 9
Description: Cutscene where Roy Earle walks into a meeting between some very important people and tells them to use Cole Phelps as a cover up for the Brenda thing. They ask what he wants in return.

Name: Newspaper 10
Description: Ira calls and tells Doctor Fontaine that he has a purpose to bring everyone to heaven with the fires.

Name: Newspaper 11
Description: Courtney confronts Fontaine about the Suburban Redevelopment Fund and then kills Courtney.

Name: Newspaper 12
Description: Cole reaches Courtney's corpse and then Earle comes and tells Cole to get away. Cole pulls his gun on Earle and then tells him to stay away and that he'll get him good.

Name: Newspaper 13
Description: It's a talk between Fontaine and Monroe. Monroe is complaining that Ira is out of control, and Fontaine says that he killed Sheldon. Monroe says he'll take care of Kelso and Fontaine will take care of Ira.
